title: Tech Start Up
question_text:
Pete is starting a new job at a tech start-up. He is wondering about the age breakdown of the employees who currently work at the company. Given is the cumulative relative frequency graph summarizing the employees' ages:
What statement is supported by the cumulative relative frequency graph of employee ages?

choices.text: The oldest employee is $70$ years old.
Over $50\%$ of employees are younger than $40$ years old.
Over one-fourth of the employees are younger than $30$ years old.
$25\%$ of employees are aged between $50$ and $60$ years old.
The youngest employee at the company is $20$ years old.

solution:
Solution

The ages of employees at the tech start-up are summarized in a cumulative relative frequency graph, or Ogive. A cumulative graph represents the number or proportion of a data set less than or equal to a given number. You can find the proportion of data points in a certain interval by finding the percent for the upper bound and the percent for the lower bound and subtracting the two values.

When looking at this ogive, to find the proportion of employees younger than $40$, follow the horizontal axis until you get to $40$ years old. Then move vertically until you hit the line graph, and make a right angle to the vertical axis. You find the proportion of employees $40$ years old or younger is approximately $0.52$, which is over half of the employees.

Choice 'B' is correct.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. Although the horizontal axis is labeled to $70$, this does not imply the oldest employee is $70$, just that all employees are younger than $70$ years old.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. If you follow the same procedure to find the proportion of employees younger than $30$, you see that it is just under $25\%$, so it is not one-fourth.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. Since the proportion of employees under $60$ is approximately $0.95$ and the proportion of employees under $50$ is approximately $0.82$, the proportion between the two is only $0.13$.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. Again, even though the horizontal axis has a minimum of $20$ years old, this does not imply the youngest employee is $20$, just that all employees are older than $20$ years old.
